R. China ⁎ Correspoding author. Polluting gas CO has attracted wide attention because of its toxicity to human health. Thus, it is urgent for the removal of CO. Herein, a series of Pd supported on UiO-66 catalysts were prepared by ethylene glycol reduction and the supported 0.5 wt% Pd on UiO-66 (0.5Pd-66) was used to investigate the influence of pretreatment conditions. It was found that the 0.5Pd-66 pretreated under O2 atmosphere (0.5Pd-66-O) possessed the better CO oxidation performance, which could completely oxide CO to CO2 at 165 °C. A series of characterization results indicated that the surface area, reduction ability at low temperature, particle size of Pd nanoparticles and surface chemical state of the catalyst were great influenced by pretreatment conditions. The better catalytic performance of 0.5Pd-66-O was ascribed to the high surface area, better reducibility at low temperature, small Pd NPs and more Pd2+ and Olat species. More importantly, the CO oxidation mechanism was proposed by in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy of CO oxidation over 0.5Pd-66-O. This work has guiding significance for studying the effect of reaction atmosphere on the structure and activity of catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO oxidation Pd-UiO-66 catalysts Pretreatment condition MOFs 1 Introduction Carbon monoxide (CO) is the most abundant and widely distributed in the atmosphere. It is the product of incomplete combustion of carbonaceous materials such as coal and petroleum [1,2]. With the continuous development of transportation and industrial and mining enterprises in various countries around the world, the consumption of coal and petroleum fuels continues to increase, and carbon monoxide emissions are also increasing. Excessive CO emissions into the air will cause air pollution [3,4]. Additionally, CO breathing into humans and animals will bind to hemoglobin in the blood and cause hypoxia, causing CO poisoning and death [5]. Thus, the removal of CO is imminent. Catalytic oxidation was considered to be one of the most efficient methods for gaseous pollutions [6-8]. Catalytic oxidation CO to CO2 at low temperature is one of the important methods for air purification and green chemistry [9]. And CO oxidation is very important not only in fundamental science but also in a wide range of industrial fields, including automobiles and fuel cell systems [10]. For the removal of CO, many catalysts, including metal oxides, noble metal and supported noble metal catalysts, have been used [11-13]. Recently, metal organic frameworks, which consist of metal ions connected by organic bridging ligands to a porous structure, have attracted much research interest due to their superiority in gas storage [14], adsorption [15,16], photocatalysis [17-19], catalytic oxidation [20,21] and so on. Because of their high porosity and designability, MOFs had also received increasing interest as a functional support material for metal nanocatalysts. For example, Cao et al. [22] prepared MOF-based Pd@UiO-66-NH2@ZnIn2S4 flower-like nanocomposites which exhibited excellent photocatalysis performance for hydrogen production. Abbasi et al. [23] synthesized Pd supported on various MOFs (MIL-101(Cr), MIL-101-NH2(Cr), Cu-BTC) which exhibited great catalytic performance for CO oxidation. Thus, MOFs are the great platform to supported noble metal for many catalytic reactions. Due to the excellent thermal stability, high surface area and great water and organic solvent resistance, Zr-based metal organic framework UiO-66 was diffusely used to support noble metal [24-26]. For example, Zhang et al. [27] prepared UiO-66 supported Pt nanocatalysts by NaBH4 and H2 reduction. The catalysts displayed good durability for CO oxidation. Yazdi et al. [28] prepared core-shell Au/CeO2 supported in UiO-66, which could completely oxidation CO to CO2 at 100 °C. Additionally, our previous work [29] found that the Pd nanoparticles (NPs) supported on UiO-66 exhibited excellent catalytic performance for toluene oxidation. Although there had been many researches on MOF loaded noble metals for CO oxidation, few researchers paid attention to the influence of pretreatment conditions or reaction atmosphere on the catalyst. In this work, a series of catalysts, Pd supported on UiO-66, were prepared. The 0.5Pd-66 (0.5 wt% Pd supported on UiO-66) was selected to investigate the effect of pretreatment conditions to Pd species and structure of UiO-66. The N2 adsorption-desorption curves, pore size distribution, H2 temperature programmed reduction, transmission electron microscope and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy showed that different pretreatment conditions could affect the surface area, reduction ability, the size of Pd NPs and surface chemical state and further influence the catalytic performance for CO oxidation. Importantly, a possible CO oxidation mechanism was revealed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All the chemicals were A.R. grade and used directly. The detail information of those chemicals is described in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Catalysts preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of the MOFs supports UiO-66 was prepared by the traditional solvothermal method followed our previous work [29]. 0.053 g of ZrCl4 (0.227 mmol) and 0.034 g of terephthalic acid (H2BDC, 0.227 mmol) were dissolved in 5 mL N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) by ultrasound. Then, the clarified solution is transferred to the autoclave kept at 120 °C for 24 h. After cooled down to the room temperature, the UiO-66 powder could be obtained by centrifugation, washing with ethanol for several times and dried in an oven at 70 °C overnight. 2.2.3 Preparation of the supported Pd catalysts The supported Pd catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation method, using ethylene glycol (EG) as the solvent and reductant. The preparation method was followed our previous method [20]. Generally, 1.0 g of UiO-66 was placed in 150 mL EG, stirred until completely dispersed. Then, an amount of acetic solution of Pd(OAc)2 (3.133 mmol/L) was added dropwise to the above suspension and stirred for 0.5 h. Finally, the mixed solution was heated to 150 °C and reacted for 2 h under vigorous stirring. After that, the mixed solution was cooled down to the ambient temperature. After centrifugation, washing with deionized water and ethanol several times and drying in an oven at 70 °C overnight, the catalyst named xPd-66 could obtained. x was the theoretical load of Pd (0.1, 0.3 0.5 and 0.8 wt%). In addition, Pd-66 pretreated under H2, O2 (30% O2/Ar) and reaction atmosphere (1.05% CO, 20% O2 and N2 balanced) at 200 °C for 2 h was named as xPd-66-H, xPd-66-O and xPd-66-CO, respectively. Furthermore, after CO oxidation, these catalysts xPd-66, xPd-66-H, xPd-66-O and xPd-66-CO were donated as xPd-66-A, xPd-66-H-A, xPd-66-O-A and xPd-66-CO-A, respectively. 2.3 Characterization The physicochemical parameters and morphology of the samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, N2 adsorption-desorption, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), thermogravimetric (TG), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), CO chemisorption, CO2 adsorption and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of CO adsorption and oxidation. The detail information of these characterization technologies is described in Supporting Information. 2.4 Catalysts test The CO oxidation experiment was carried out on a fixed bed microreactor. Typically, 0.1 g of catalyst was pressed and screened out between 20 and 40 mesh. A U-type quartz tube (outside diameter is 6 mm, inside diameter is 4 nm) was used to place the samples. The reaction gas (1.05% CO, 20% O2 and N2 balanced) was controlled by a mass flowmeter and the flow rate was set at 30 mL/min, namely, weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was 18,000 mL/(g•h). To study the influence of water to the samples, the water vapors (5.0 and 10.0 Vol.%) were introduced by a water saturator. The amount of water vapors was calculated by our previous work [29]. An online gas chromatograph (GC2060, Ruimin, Shanghai) equipped with a flam ionization detector (FID) was used to detect the CO concentration in the inlet and outlet gas. Temperatures with CO conversion rate of 50% and 98% (T50 and T98) were used to estimate the catalytic activity of the catalysts. The CO conversion (XCO) was calculated by the following formula: X CO = ( C 0 − C 1 ) / C 0 × 100 % where, C0 and C1 were the CO concentration of the inlet and outlet gas, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 CO catalytic performance of the xPd-66 catalysts Fig. S1 shows the XRD patterns of UiO-66 and the xPd-66. The XRD pattern of UiO-66 is in line with our previous works [21], indicating its successfully synthesis. After the introduction of Pd, the intensity of diffraction peaks is decreased and with the increase of Pd loading, the diffraction peaks decreased gradually. The decrease of XRD patterns of UiO-66 might be due to that during the reduction process, the EG interacted with UiO-66, resulting in the deterioration of the crystal form of UiO-66. This was in consistence with our previous work [29] and could be confirmed by the TG curves (Fig. S2) which will discussed later. Notably, no peaks of Pd or PdO can be found in the XRD patterns, which may be ascribed to the low loading or high dispersion of Pd spices [30]. Fig. 1 (A) shows the CO conversion over the xPd-66 catalysts. The T50 and T98 were used to estimate the catalytic efficiency of the xPd-66 catalysts, and the results are listed in Table S1. The T98 of 0.1Pd-66, 0.3Pd-66, 0.5Pd-66 and 0.8Pd-66 are 199, 189, 180 and 180 °C, respectively. With the Pd loadings increase from 0.1 wt% to 0.5 wt%, the CO oxidation performance increased gradually. However, the catalytic activity of CO did not increase with the further increase of Pd loading to 0.8 wt%. Thus, the 0.5Pd-66 was selected for further study. Fig. 1(B) shows the CO recycle oxidation reaction of 0.5Pd-66. Interesting, As the number of cycles increases, the catalytic performance of 0.5Pd-66 increased until the furth times. The T98 of 0.5Pd-66 decreased from 180 to 155 °C. To understand the reason why the enhanced catalytic performance of 0.5Pd-66 for CO oxidation, 0.5Pd-66 was pretreated at different condition (H2, O2 and reaction gas atmosphere). 3.2 Characterization of the 0.5Pd-66 catalyst with different pretreat conditions Fig. 2 (A) shows the XRD patterns of UiO-66 0.5Pd-66 and the pretreated 0.5Pd-66. The XRD patterns of these pretreated 0.5Pd-66 present the similar peak shapes and are consistent with the peak shape of 0.5Pd-66. This result indicates that the pretreat conditions had no influence on the crystal structure of 0.5Pd-66. Fig. 2(B) shows the FT-IR spectra of UiO-66, 0.5Pd-66 and the pretreated 0.5Pd-66. All the supported 0.5Pd catalysts present the similar spectra with UiO-66, indicating that the introduction of Pd and the pretreatment conditions have hardly influence on the structure of UiO-66. However, compared with UiO-66, the band is disappeared in the supported 0.5Pd catalysts, which is attributed to the C=O of DMF at 1660 cm−1 [31]. This may be ascribed to that the residual DMF was removed during the EG reduction or washing process. In addition, after the introduction of Pd NPs, some new bands at the regions of 2950–2850 cm−1 and 1200–800 cm−1 which represented to EG was appeared [32], indicated that EG remained on the surface of the catalysts. In a word, the XRD and FT-IR results indicate the pretreatment condition had not influence on the structure of 0.5Pd-66. Fig. S2 shows the TG curves of UiO-66 and supported 0.5Pd catalysts. The UiO-66 structure collapses at a temperature of about 500 °C. However, after the introduction of Pd, the structures of supported 0.5Pd catalysts collapse at about 430 °C, because of EG interacted with the linkers of UiO-66 led to the deterioration of the crystal form and structural stability of UiO-66 during reduction progress, which was in consistence with the XRD patterns. For UiO-66, the TG curve can divide into three stages [33,34]. The first stage was at 30–100 °C, which could attributed to the loss of crystal water in the structure. The weight loss between 100 and 300 °C was ascribed to the loss of the residual DMF and impurities. The stage at above 300 °C was due to the structural collapse and finally formed ZrO2. After EG reduction, the shape of TG curves for the supported 0.5Pd catalysts have an obvious distinction. For 0.5Pd-66, the weight loss at 100–200 °C was attributed to the lost water and impurities. The second stage at 200–230 °C might be ascribed to the loss of residual EG. The existence of EG was confirmed by FT-IR. The final stage, above 230 °C, was attributed to the structural collapse. The difference of TG curves between UiO-66 and 0.5Pd-66 might lead to the change of pore structure, which will be discussed later. After pretreated at different conditions, the shapes of these TG curves for 0.5Pd-66-H, 0.5Pd-66-O and 0.5Pd-66-CO were similar and were consistent with 0.5Pd-66. Even so, there are still subtle differences between 0.5Pd-66-H, 0.5Pd-66-O and 0.5Pd-66-CO. These subtle differences might be related to the pore structure. The physical absorption was used to characterize the specific surface area and pore structure. The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) model. The density functional-theory (DFT) and Barrett Joyner Halenda (BJH) method were used to calculated the pore diameter. Fig. 2(C, D and E) present the N2 adsorption-desorption, pore size distribution calculated by DFT and BJH method, respectively. The values of BET surface area (SBET), pore volume and pore diameter calculated by DFT (DDFT) and BJH (DBJH) method are summarized in Table 1 . UiO-66 exhibit a typical micropore structure with the SBET and pore volume of 1335 m2/g and 0.833 cc/g, respectively [35]. The pore size distribution (Fig. 2(D and E)) also confirmed its micropore structure. After the introduction of Pd, the N2 adsorption-desorption curve of 0.5Pd-66 appeared a small hysteresis loop, which indicated that the pore structure of UiO-66 was changed. This is consistent with the TG result. In addition, the appearance of mesoporous in 0.5Pd-66 also demonstrated the change of pore structure. After pretreated at different conditions, the hysteresis loop became bigger, indicated the appearance of more mesoporous. The SBET and total pore volume of 0.5Pd-66, 0.5Pd-66-H, 0.5Pd-66-O and 0.5Pd-66-CO are 682 m2/g and 0.389 cc/g, 340 m2/g and 0.351 cc/g, 859 m2/g and 0.491 cc/g, 626 m2/g and 0.405 cc/g, respectively. 0.5Pd-66-O possesses the largest SBET and pore volume. The changes of SBET, pore volume and pore size distribution (Fig. 2(D and E)) are closely related to the pretreatment condition. In addition, to determine the small micropore of the samples, the CO2 adsorption was performed. Fig. S3 shows the CO2 adsorption curves and pore size distribution calculated by Dolimore-Heal (DH) method. It can be found that compared with UiO-66, the uptake of CO2 of the supported 0.5Pd increased at different degree. All the samples present the similar small micropore distribution. Fig. 3 shows the TEM and the size distribution of Pd NPs of the supported 0.5Pd catalysts and HRTEM of 0.5Pd-66-O. It can be found that the Pd NPs were evenly distributed on the UiO-66 support. The average size of Pd NPs on 0.5Pd-66, 0.5Pd-66-H, 0.5Pd-66-O and 0.5Pd-66-CO are 6.3, 6.25, 5.26 and 6.01 nm, respectively. Among them, the 0.5Pd-66-O possesses the smallest Pd NPs. In addition, the HRTEM of 0.5Pd-66-O (Fig. 3(E)) displays a lattice spacing of 0.22 nm (Fig. 3(F)), corresponding to the Pd (111) plane. The TEM results indicated that the Pd NPs were successfully loaded on UiO-66 and the 0.5Pd-66 possessed the smallest Pd NPs. To determine the surface chemical composition, the XPS was used. Fig. 4 and Fig. S4 show the XPS spectra of the supported 0.5Pd catalysts. The XPS full spectra (Fig. S4) confirm that the C, O, Zr and Pd exist in the supported 0.5Pd catalysts. Fig. 4(A) shows the Zr 3d spectra. The Zr 3d spectra can be divided into two peaks at 185.2 (Zr 3d3/2) and 182.8 eV (Zr 3d5/2) assigned to Zr4+ in Zr-O clusters [30]. The O 1 s spectra (Fig. 4(B)) are fitted into three peaks at 533.3, 531.7 and 530.3 eV, corresponding to surface OH (OOH), adsorption oxygen (Oads) and lattice oxygen (Olat) [36-38]. The molar ratios of Olat to Oads calculated by the peak area are listed in Table 1. The values of Olat/Oads for 0.5Pd-66, 0.5Pd-66-H, 0.5Pd-66-O and 0.5Pd-66-CO are 0.181, 0.244, 0.268 and 0.263, respectively. 0.5Pd-66-O presents the highest Olat/Oads value. Fig. 4(C) shows the Pd 3d spectra of the supported 0.5Pd catalysts, the fitting peaks at 336.8 and 335.0 eV correspond to the Pd2+ and Pd0 species [20,29]. The values of Pd2+/Pd° for the supported 0.5Pd catalysts are summarized in Table 1. Among these catalysts, 0.5Pd-66-O possesses the highest Pd2+/Pd0 value (0.236). In short, the XPS results indicate 0.5Pd-66-O possesses the highest Olat/Oads and Pd2+/Pd0 values. To learn the reducibility of the supported 0.5Pd catalysts, the H2-TPR was performed. As shown in Fig. 5 (A), the supported 0.5Pd catalysts present the similar H2-TPR files. All the supported 0.5Pd catalysts display the similar curves. For UiO-66, only one peak appeared at the range of 450–600 °C, which was ascribed to the collapse of framework [39]. After the introduction of Pd NPs, a new negative peak appeared at about 100 °C, which was attributed to the reduction of Pd2+ to Pd0 [40] and the hydrogen spillover between UiO-66 and Pd [41]. In addition, the peak between 400 and 600 °C shifted to a lower temperature, which indicated that the introduction of Pd NPs accelerated the collapse of UiO-66 structure. This is consistent with the TG result. When 0.5Pd-66 pretreated at different conditions, it was no obvious influence on the UiO-66 structure. However, the reduction peak of Pd2+ (Fig. 5(B)) changed a lot. The negative peaks deviate to low temperature in different degrees and become more pronounced. The appearance of the more obvious negative peaks indicated more Pd2+ species in the pretreated 0.5Pd-66, which may be due to the influence of pretreatment atmospheres to Pd species. This is in accord with the XPS result. Additionally, the reduction peak of Pd2+ for 0.5Pd-66-O appeared at the lowest temperature (94 °C), indicating the 0.5Pd-66-O possesses the best reducibility at low temperature. 3.3 CO catalytic performance of the 0.5Pd-66 catalyst with different pretreat conditions Fig. 6 shows the temperature dependent CO conversion of 0.5Pd-66 and pretreated 0.5Pd-66 catalysts. The T50% and T98% of the supported 0.5Pd catalysts are summarized in Table S1. The T98% of 0.5Pd-66, 0.5Pd-66-H, 0.5Pd-66-O and 0.5Pd-66-CO are 180, 176, 163 and 170 °C, respectively. It can be found that the 0.5Pd-66-O exhibits the better catalytic performance for CO oxidation. The catalytic efficiency of the four catalysts ranked as: 0.5Pd-66-O > 0.5Pd-66-CO > 0.5Pd-66-H > 0.5Pd-66. Compared with the reported works (Table 2 ) [42–46], the 0.5Pd-66-O exhibits better catalytic performance. For kinetic study, t the first order kinetic analysis of CO oxidation was carried out. The CO concentration, and extra oxygen and oxygen concentration are closely related to the mechanism: r = − kc = [ − A e x p ( − Ea / RT ) ] c where k, r, Ea, and A refer to rate constant (s −1), reaction rate (μmol/(g•s)), apparent activation energy (kJ/mol), and pre-exponential factor, respectively. It is noting that the conversion rate below 20% to use this formula to calculate activation energy (Ea) and the results display in Fig. 6(B). As shown in Fig. 6(B), the Ea value decreases as follows: 0.5Pd-66-O (63.4 kJ/mol) < 0.5Pd-66-CO (65.3 kJ/mol) < 0.5Pd-66-H (67.4 kJ/mol) < 0.5Pd-66 (160.7 kJ/mol). The Ea values of 0.5Pd-66-O are smaller than that of other supported Pd catalysts, which indicates that 0.5Pd-66-O possessed the best catalytic activity for CO oxidation. Typically, the CO oxidation performance is affected by many factors, such as the surface area and reducibility at low temperature of the catalyst, the size of active species, chemical state of surface element, oxygen species and so on. It has been reported that the high specific surface area is beneficial for the mass transport to improve the catalytic performance [47]. The 0.5Pd-66-O possesses the highest SBET among the supported 0.5Pd catalysts, which led to the great catalytic performance for CO oxidation. Our previous works shows that the better reducibility at low temperature of a catalyst usually exhibited a better catalytic performance [46,48]. The H2-TPR result shows that the 0.5Pd-66-O have a better reducibility at low temperature. Thus, the better reduction ability at low temperature of 0.5Pd-66-O can account for its better CO oxidation activity. In addition, many researchers have investigated the size effect of the noble metal NPs to the catalytic activity [49-51]. They found that different size of noble metal NPs could bring about different metal dispersion, chemical state and strongly effect the catalytic performance. And the smaller the size of the noble metal NPs, the better the catalytic activity. For 0.5Pd-66-O, the average size of Pd NPs is 5.26 nm which is the smallest among the supported 0.5Pd-66 catalysts. So, the smallest size of Pd NPs in 0.5Pd-66-O was one of the factors for the better CO oxidation. Additionally, according to the XPS results, 0.5Pd-66-O possesses more Olat and Pd2+ species. Generally, the CO oxidation follows Mars Van Krevelen mechanism [52,53] CO + Pd2+O2−→ CO2 + Pd0. The Olat can directly activate gaseous CO in the oxidation reaction [28]. In addition, Li et al. [54] have been reported that the low-temperature catalytic activity exhibited for CO oxidation could be associated with the presence of Pd2+ species rather than Pd0 nanoparticles. Moreover, Yang et al. [55] found that the lattice oxygen can involve in the redox cycle of Pd0 and Pd2+ in the oxidative carbonylation of phenol to diphenyl carbonate. Thus, more Pd2+ and Olat species can enhance the oxidation reaction [56]. In a word, the better catalytic performance of 0.5Pd-66-O for CO oxidation was attributed to the high surface area, low temperature reduction ability, small Pd NPs and more Pd2+ and Olat species. Furthermore, the CO uptake obtained from CO chemisorption (Table 1) of the supported 0.5Pd catalysts also confirmed the better catalytic performance of 0.5Pd-66-O. Fig. 1(B) and Fig. 6(B, C and D) show the reusability of 0.5Pd-66, 0.5Pd-66-H, 0.5Pd-66-O and 0.5Pd-66-CO, respectively. It can be found that the 0.5Pd-66 and pretreated 0.5Pd-66 catalysts possess great reusability. In addition, with the increase of recycle, the catalytic performance of the three catalysts also increased in different degree. It is worth noting that no matter under what pretreatment conditions, the catalyst can always obtain similar catalytic activity after multiple cycles, which indicates that the reaction atmosphere (1.05% CO, 20% O2 and N2 balanced) further stabilized the catalyst structure. Additionally, the XPS spectra (Fig. S5) of 0.5Pd-66 and 0.5Pd-66-O after reaction indicated the increase of Pd2+ species (Table S2), which could be a reason for the increased catalytic performance. To investigate the effect of WHSV, stability and water resistance of the catalysts, 0.5Pd-66-O was selected. Fig 7 (A) shows the effect of WHSV on 0.5Pd-66-O for CO oxidation. With the increase of WHSV, the catalytic performance decreased a lot, which may be ascribed to the high WHSV value decreased the molar ratio of reactive oxygen species to CO molecules on the surface, restraining CO oxidation. The stability test of 0.5Pd-66-O was performed at different temperature (Fig. 7(B)). At a low temperature (150 °C), about 27% CO can convert to CO2 for 10 h. When the temperature rase to 165 °C, the CO conversion rate increased rapidly and reached complete conversion. Then reduce the temperature to 160 and 155 °C, the CO conversion rate can still maintain complete conversion, indicating the great stability of 0.5Pd-66-O. In addition, the XRD patterns, FT-IR spectra, N2 adsorption-desorption curves and pore size distribution (Fig. S6) of the supported 0.5Pd catalysts after reaction also indicated the stability of these catalysts. Fig. 7(C) exhibits the water resistance of 0.5Pd-66-O at 150 and 165 °C. Regardless of the low temperature or high temperature, the conversion rate of CO would decrease after the water was introduced. When the water vapor was turned off, the CO conversion would gradually recover, which indicated that 0.5Pd-66-O has better water resistance. In short, the 0.5Pd-66-O have good stability and water resistance. 3.4 In situ DRIFTS of CO adsorption and oxidation mechanism To investigate the CO adsorption and oxidation mechanism over 0.5Pd-66-O, the in situ DRIFTS was carried out. Fig. 8 showed the in situ DRIFTS spectra of CO adsorption and oxidation. Fig. 8(A) showed the CO adsorption spectra. The bands at 2170 and 2108 cm−1 were ascribed to the adsorption of gaseous CO on 0.5Pd-66-O [57,58]. The other two bands at 2027 and 1975 cm−1 were attributed to the chemisorption of CO in the form of bridging adsorption [59-61]. With the increase of time, the adsorption intensity of CO increased. After exposure to CO for 1 h, the gas was switched to Ar to study the adsorption intensity of CO on 0.5Pd-66-O. It can be found from Fig. 8(B) that as Ar purge time increased, the adsorption strength of CO decreased gradually. Especially, the bands of 2170 and 2108 cm−1 for the adsorption of gaseous CO on 0.5Pd-66-O were disappeared. This indicated that the gaseous CO adsorbed on the catalyst surface could not exist stably. Furtherly, to study the CO oxidation mechanism over 0.5Pd-66-O, 30 vol.% O2/Ar was introduced to the in situ cell after exposure to CO for 1 h. Fig. 8(C) presented the in situ DRIFTS spectra of CO oxidation on the surface of the 0.5Pd-66-O at 150 °C at different times. With time increased, the absorbed bands at 2170, 2108 cm−1 and 2027, 1975 cm−1 were ascribed to the absorbed gaseous CO molecules and chemisorption CO on Pd(111), respectively, gradually weaken and disappeared. Simultaneously, some new bands were appeared. The band at 1443 cm−1 was ascribed to the presence of bicarbonate species (HCO3 −), which indicated that the HCO3 − was produced during CO oxidation [62,63]. In addition, the peak at 1248 cm−1 which was assigned to the asymmetric bicarbonate species also confirmed the exitance of HCO3 − species. The bands between 1300 and 1400 cm−1 were ascribed to monodentate carbonates species (m-CO3 2−) [63,64]. The band at 1581 cm−1 was attributed to νas(OCO) stretching vibration of bidentate carbonate species (b-CO3 2−) [60,64]. The appearance of these bands indicated the HCO3 −, m-CO3 2− and b-CO3 2− are the main intermediates during CO oxidation. Additionally, the absorbance peak appeared at 2233 cm−1 was attributed to the CO2 species, indicating the formation of gaseous CO2. Based on the above studies, it could be found that the oxidation pathway of CO on the surface of the 0.5Pd-66-O catalyst could be carried out. CO was first adsorbed on Pd NPs, Then the rapid transformation of CO to various carbon-related species (HCO3 −, b-CO3 2− and m-CO3 2− species) and finally decomposed into gaseous CO2. 4 Conclusion In summary, a range of xPd-66 catalysts were prepared by EG reduction. The Pd loads were first investigated for CO oxidation. It was found that with the increase of Pd loadings, the catalytic performance for CO oxidation first increased. When the Pd loadings increased to 0.8 wt%, the CO oxidation activity was similar to the 0.5 wt% Pd. In addition, the reusability test of 0.5Pd-66 shows that with the increase of recycle number, the catalytic performance increased a lot. Thus, the 0.5Pd-66 was selected to investigate the effect of pretreatment conditions. It was found that compared with pretreated under H2, reaction gas (CO) atmosphere, 0.5Pd-66-O pretreated under O2 atmosphere showed the better catalytic performance for CO oxidation. The CO could completely convert to CO2 at 165 °C over 0.5Pd-66-O. A series of characterization results indicated that the pretreatment conditions could influence the surface area, reduction ability at low temperature, particle size of Pd NPs and surface chemical state of the catalyst. The better catalytic performance of 0.5Pd-66-O was ascribed to the high surface area, better reducibility at low temperature, small Pd NPs and more Pd2+ and Olat species. Importantly, the possible oxidation pathway of CO on the surface of the 0.5Pd-66-O catalyst was revealed. CO was first adsorbed on Pd NPs, Then the rapid transformation of CO to various carbon-related species (HCO3 −, b-CO3 2− and m-CO3 2− species) and finally decomposed into gaseous CO2. This work may inspire researchers to pay attention to the effect of reaction atmosphere on catalyst structure CRediT authorship contribution statement Fukun Bi: Writing - original draft. coredata.dc:description: Polluting gas CO has attracted wide attention because of its toxicity to human health. Thus, it is urgent for the removal of CO. Herein, a series of Pd supported on UiO-66 catalysts were prepared by ethylene glycol reduction and the supported 0.5 wt% Pd on UiO-66 (0.5Pd-66) was used to investigate the influence of pretreatment conditions. It was found that the 0.5Pd-66 pretreated under O2 atmosphere (0.5Pd-66-O) possessed the better CO oxidation performance, which could completely oxide CO to CO2 at 165 °C. A series of characterization results indicated that the surface area, reduction ability at low temperature, particle size of Pd nanoparticles and surface chemical state of the catalyst were great influenced by pretreatment conditions. The better catalytic performance of 0.5Pd-66-O was ascribed to the high surface area, better reducibility at low temperature, small Pd NPs and more Pd2+ and Olat species. More importantly, the CO oxidation mechanism was proposed by in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy of CO oxidation over 0.5Pd-66-O. This work has guiding significance for studying the effect of reaction atmosphere on the structure and activity of catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of pretreatment conditions on low-temperature CO oxidation over Pd supported UiO-66 catalysts
